message_1: A hyperbolic triangle has angles $30^\circ$, $40^\circ$, and $110^\circ$. What is the area of this triangle in hyperbolic geometry?
message_2:
In hyperbolic geometry, the area of a hyperbolic triangle is given by the formula:

Area = π - (α + β + γ)

where α, β, and γ are the angles of the triangle. In this case, we have:

α = 30° = π/6 radians
β = 40° = 2π/9 radians
γ = 110° = 11π/18 radians

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

Area = π - (π/6 + 2π/9 + 11π/18)
Area = π - (3π/18 + 4π/18 + 11π/18)
Area = π - (18π/18)
Area = π - π
Area = 0

The area of this hyperbolic triangle is 0.
